tool.name: featuretoRaster

param.name: inFC
param.dialogReference: The input feature class or shapefile that will be converted to a raster.
param.pythonReference: The input feature class or shapefile that will be converted to a raster.

param.name: out_raster
param.dialogReference: The location and name of the output raster file. The file extension determines the format that the raster will be saved to. The recommended file extension is .tif, which will produce a raster in geoTIFF format. GeoTIFF is the optimal format for use in WRO services.
param.pythonReference: The location and name of the output raster file. The file extension determines the format that the raster will be saved to. The recommended file extension is .tif, which will produce a raster in geoTIFF format. GeoTIFF is the optimal format for use in WRO services.

param.name: processname
param.dialogReference:
• Present/Absent: This method is used to produce a binary raster. The output will be a raster where all output pixels that correspond to the presence of a feature in the input feature class have a value representing presence (usually a value of 1), and the rest of the output extent is filled with NoData. For example, if you have a feature class representing critical habitat for several species, you may want to output a raster that indicates whether any given area is critical habitat of any kind, regardless of species. To do this, you may want to add a field to your feature class called presence, and use the field calculator to set all the values to 1. You would then select the presence field to produce a raster that indicates presence of critical habitat (raster value = 1), and absence of critical habitat (raster value = NoData).

  • Key Attribute: This method is similar to the Present/Absent method, except that you would use an attribute that has variability. The resulting raster will have pixel values that represent the value of the key attribute of the feature class at the corresponding location.

  • Density: This method produces a raster where the cell values represent the density of features in or around that cell. The input features must be polylines or points. A moving window is used to analyze features within the window and assign that value to the cell. The size of this window can be adjusted via the Search Radius option. If a polyline feature class is input, the output cell values will be length of lines within the moving window around each cell. If a point feature class is input, the output cell values will be number of points within the moving window around each cell. However, the output values can also be weighted by a field in the feature class, so that output cells corresponding to features that have a high value for the specified field will be weighted more heavily than those corresponding to features that have a low value for the specified field.

  • Distance: This method produces an output raster where the cell values represent the distance from the closest input feature. Common uses are distance from roads or distance to water.
param.pythonReference:
• Present/Absent: This method is used to produce a binary raster. The output will be a raster where all output pixels that correspond to the presence of a feature in the input feature class have a value representing presence (usually a value of 1), and the rest of the output extent is filled with NoData. For example, if you have a feature class representing critical habitat for several species, you may want to output a raster that indicates whether any given area is critical habitat of any kind, regardless of species. To do this, you may want to add a field to your feature class called presence, and use the field calculator to set all the values to 1. You would then select the presence field to produce a raster that indicates presence of critical habitat (raster value = 1), and absence of critical habitat (raster value = NoData).

  • Key Attribute: This method is similar to the Present/Absent method, except that you would use an attribute that has variability. The resulting raster will have pixel values that represent the value of the key attribute of the feature class at the corresponding location.

  • Density: This method produces a raster where the cell values represent the density of features in or around that cell. The input features must be polylines or points. A moving window is used to analyze features within the window and assign that value to the cell. The size of this window can be adjusted via the Search Radius option. If a polyline feature class is input, the output cell values will be length of lines within the moving window around each cell. If a point feature class is input, the output cell values will be number of points within the moving window around each cell. However, the output values can also be weighted by a field in the feature class, so that output cells corresponding to features that have a high value for the specified field will be weighted more heavily than those corresponding to features that have a low value for the specified field.

  • Distance: This method produces an output raster where the cell values represent the distance from the closest input feature. Common uses are distance from roads or distance to water.

param.name: cellSize
param.dialogReference:
The cell size for the output raster. Units are the linear units of the projection of the input feature class.

Sample python code to calculate cell size based on feature layer extent. To use this code snippet, paste it into the python window in ArcGIS desktop.

ext=arcpy.Describe("your-layer").extent

if ext.width < ext.height:

cellsize=ext.width/250

else:

cellsize=ext.height/250

print cellsize

You can also use the same cell size as specified in the snapraster.
param.pythonReference: The cell size for the output raster. Units are the linear units of the projection of the input feature class.

param.name: infield
param.dialogReference: The field used to assign values to the output raster. Used for rasterization methods that allow or require a field.
param.pythonReference: The field used to assign values to the output raster. Used for rasterization methods that allow or require a field.

param.name: outputextent
param.dialogReference: Extent of output raster. Can be used to limit processing to a specified area.
param.pythonReference: Extent of output raster. Can be used to limit processing to a specified area.

param.name: snapraster
param.dialogReference: An existing raster to which cells in the output raster will be aligned.
param.pythonReference: An existing raster to which cells in the output raster will be aligned.

param.name: maskEnv
param.dialogReference: It will only consider the cell that fall within the analysis mask in the operation

param.name: searchradius
param.dialogReference:
The search radius within which to calculate density. Units are based on the linear unit of the projection of the output spatial reference.

For example, if the units are in meters, to include all features within a one-mile neighborhood, set the search radius equal to 1609.344 (1 mile = 1609.344 meters).

The default is the shortest of the width or height of the output extent in the output spatial reference, divided by 30.
param.pythonReference:
The search radius within which to calculate density. Units are based on the linear unit of the projection of the output spatial reference.

For example, if the units are in meters, to include all features within a one-mile neighborhood, set the search radius equal to 1609.344 (1 mile = 1609.344 meters).

The default is the shortest of the width or height of the output extent in the output spatial reference, divided by 30.

tool.summary: Converts features to rasters for use in a mosaic dataset that will be served as a Weighted Raster Overlay (WRO) service.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Converts features to rasters for use in a mosaic dataset that will be served as a Weighted Raster Overlay (WRO) service.
